title: Embassy of the United States, Vienna
text:
The Embassy of the United States of America in Vienna is the main <a href="List%20of%20diplomatic%20missions%20of%20the%20United%20States">United States diplomatic mission</a> to <a href="Austria">Austria</a>. Since 1947 the embassy building is located on Boltzmanngasse 16, in the <a href="Alsergrund">Alsergrund</a> district of <a href="Vienna">Vienna</a>.
History.
The United States first established diplomatic relations with Austria when <a href="Henry%20A.%20P.%20Muhlenberg">Henry A. P. Muhlenberg</a> was appointed first U.S. <a href="Envoy%20%28title%29">Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary</a> to the <a href="Austrian%20Empire">Austrian Empire</a> on 8 February 1838. When according to the <a href="Austro-Hungarian%20Compromise%20of%201867">Compromise of 1867</a> the empire became the union of <a href="Austria-Hungary">Austria-Hungary</a>, the Ministers were so commissioned. The legation officially was elevated to the status of an <a href="embassy">embassy</a> on 17 May 1902, with <a href="Robert%20Sanderson%20McCormick">Robert Sanderson McCormick</a> as first <a href="United%20States%20Ambassador%20to%20Austria">U.S. Ambassador</a>.
When upon the <a href="American%20entry%20into%20World%20War%20I">American entry into World War I</a> the United States broke off diplomatic relations with Austria-Hungary in April 1917, <a href="Restoration%20%28Spain%29">Spain</a> handled the representation of U.S. interests in Vienna for the duration of the war. In 1921 the U.S. diplomatic mission reopened as a <a href="legation">legation</a>.
The <a href="Baroque%20Revival%20architecture">Neo-baroque</a> embassy building at Boltzmanngasse 16 was constructed from 1902 to 1904 according to plans designed by architect <a href="Ludwig%20Baumann%20%28architect%29">Ludwig Baumann</a>. It was originally built as the new location of the "<a href="K.k.%20Akademie%20f%C3%BCr%20Orientalische%20Sprachen">K.k. Akademie für Orientalische Sprachen</a>", which had been established in 1754 (the precursor of the present-day <a href="Diplomatic%20Academy%20of%20Vienna">Diplomatic Academy of Vienna</a>). The studying conditions were severely restricted after the Austrian "<a href="Anschluss">Anschluss</a>" to <a href="Nazi%20Germany">Nazi Germany</a>, and the building was temporarily used as a <a href="Wehrmacht">Wehrmacht</a> military hospital. At the conclusion of <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, U.S. <a href="Allied-occupied%20Austria">occupation troops</a> seized the building until 1946.
The U.S. Government finally purchased the building on 30 June 1947, at the intercession of <a href="Eleanor%20Lansing%20Dulles">Eleanor Lansing Dulles</a> and with the consent of the Austrian <a href="National%20Council%20%28Austria%29">National Council</a>. The U.S. Mission in Austria held the status of a legation from 1947 until 1951, when it officially became an embassy, with <a href="Walter%20J.%20Donnelly">Walter J. Donnelly</a> as the first U.S. ambassador to serve in Vienna since <a href="Frederic%20Courtland%20Penfield">Frederic Courtland Penfield</a> departed in World War I.
The current Ambassador of the United States to Austria is <a href="Victoria%20Reggie%20Kennedy">Victoria Reggie Kennedy</a>.
